intro: Quamoclit coccinea var. hirsuta, commonly known as the hairy red spurge, is a perennial plant native to the southwestern United States. It is characterized by its bright red, woolly stems and leaves that are covered in fine, hairy textures. The plant produces small, yellow flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it a hardy species suitable for arid environments. Its unique appearance and drought tolerance make it a popular choice for xeriscaping and ornamental gardening.
